task.name: Sector Research Protocol
task.objective: Structured research methodology for Sector Cipher to analyze sector credibility patterns and institutional benchmarks

llm.mandate: Research must be specific, tactical, and actionable - not vague observations
Focus on what builds CREDIBILITY in this sector, not conversion
Identify both what to emulate AND what to differentiate from

inputs.input: Which institutional page is being designed

phase.title: Identify Top Credibility Performers
phase.action:
Based on sector and organization type, identify top-credibility organizations:
- If user provided organizations, analyze those plus identify additional benchmarks - Look for organizations with strong reputation and trust indicators - Mix of direct competitors and aspirational credibility benchmarks - Aim for diversity: different sizes, approaches, trust strategies
phase.output: List of organizations being analyzed for credibility patterns

phase.title: Institutional Page Architecture Analysis
phase.action:
For each organization, document their institutional page architecture:
**Section Analysis:** - What sections do they include on this page type? - What order/sequence? - What comes first (identity, mission, proof)? - Where do they place trust signals? - How do they humanize the organization? - How many sections total?
**Credibility Pattern Identification:** - What patterns appear across multiple organizations? - What seems to be "table stakes" for credibility in this sector? - What unique approaches stand out? - What sections are universally present? - What varies most between organizations?

specific-elements-to-note.element: Trust signal placement and format (certifications, logos, testimonials)

phase.output: Architecture pattern summary by section type

phase.title: What Builds Credibility in This Sector
phase.action:
Synthesize patterns to identify sector-specific credibility practices:
**High-Confidence Patterns** (appear in 70%+ of high-credibility orgs): - These are likely required for sector credibility - Recommend including unless there's strategic reason not to
**Common Patterns** (appear in 40-70% of high-credibility orgs): - These are standard but not universal - Consider for inclusion based on strategy
**Unique Approaches** (appear in <40% but from highest credibility orgs): - These might be differentiation opportunities - Evaluate for strategic fit

sector-characteristics.identify: What trust signals matter most in this sector?
What's the typical depth of organizational transparency?
How technical vs. accessible is the typical approach?
What proof types matter most (certifications, awards, testimonials)?
How do high-credibility orgs present their teams?

phase.output: Sector-specific credibility patterns and best practices

phase.title: Credibility Differentiation Gap Analysis
phase.action:
Identify what organizations are NOT doing well or consistently:
**Common Weaknesses:** - What do most organizations do poorly on their institutional pages? - Where are there obvious credibility gaps? - What stakeholder needs go unaddressed? - What sections feel weak, generic, or inauthentic?
**Saturation Points:** - What approaches are so common they no longer build trust? - What messaging is so overused it feels hollow? - Where does everyone look the same?
**Opportunities:** - Where can the user's organization stand out on credibility? - What gaps can be filled for trust advantage? - What approaches are underutilized despite being effective?

specific-gaps-to-identify.gap-type: Poor stakeholder pathways (unclear who page is for)

phase.title: Sector Benchmark Data
phase.action:
Provide credibility context for this sector:
**Credibility Benchmarks:** - Typical content depth for institutional pages in this sector - What high-credibility organizations include that others don't - What factors separate high from average credibility perception
**Success Indicators:** - What signals strong institutional credibility in this sector? - What metrics matter for page effectiveness? - What should user track post-launch?

benchmark-areas.area: Content depth expectations (word count, section count)
Trust signal density norms (how many certifications, testimonials)
Team presentation expectations (full bios, photos, credentials)
Update frequency expectations (how often content refreshed)

phase.title: Strategic Intelligence Briefing
phase.action:
Compile findings into actionable intelligence report:
**Executive Summary:** - [3-5 key insights about credibility in this sector]
**Architecture Intelligence:** - Must-have sections for sector credibility - Common patterns to consider - Unique approaches to evaluate
**Differentiation Strategy:** - Where competitors are weak on credibility - What's oversaturated (avoid copying) - Where to stand out on trust
**Benchmarks:** - Expected content depth and signals - Key credibility indicators
**Tactical Recommendations:** - Specific architecture suggestions based on research - What to emulate from high-credibility organizations - What to do differently for credibility advantage
phase.presentation-style: Present findings in Sector Cipher's voice: - "I've decoded the credibility patterns in [sector]..." - "Your competitors all [pattern], but here's the gap..." - "Based on analyzing [X] high-credibility organizations, here's what builds trust..." - Tactical, confident, intelligence-focused

outputs.output: What builds credibility in this sector

quality-standards.standard: Every insight must be specific and actionable
Patterns must be documented with frequency data
Benchmarks must include ranges and context
Recommendations must connect research to credibility outcomes

validation.check: Minimum organization count met for research depth
Intelligence briefing is tactical and credibility-focused
